body: After years of negotiation, a final division of the four boroughs outside Manhattan among six cable television companies was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Officials said service could be brought into some homes as early as June. ''In Staten Island,'' said Morris Tarshis, director of franchises, ''it could come like that'' and he
title: DELAYED YEARS, CABLE TV TO EXPAND TO ALL OF CITY

body: The six cable-television companies that were awarded rights to wire the boroughs outside of Manhattan under an agreement concluded yesterday are variously owned by large communications concerns and small local ventures. Manhattan has been served for more than a decade by Manhattan Cable TV in the southern portion and Teleprompter in the northern
title: LARGE AND SMALL COMPANIES AMONG THE WINNERS OF CABLE CONTRACTS

body: The dark sedan went down the street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, then backed up and went down the street again. The car had red and white Indiana plates. So did all the other cars parked on the street. The people who live in the neighborhood sat on the stoops. A young man in a sweatshirt, with an easy, ambling walk, came down the street
title: ABOUT NEW YORK

body: The New York City Department of Health cited 24 food establishments last week for violating the health code. In addition, the department named six that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and five that were closed after failing to do so. VIOLATIONS Chicken Burger World, 404 Ave. of the Americas. Tavola Calda da Alfredo, 285
title: 24 Food Places Listed For Health Violations

body: To the Editor: The newly opened Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn is intended to provide for neighborhoods formerly served by Greenpoint and Cumberland Hospitals, which have been discontinued as public hospitals. This does not mean, however, that they could not continue to be used in the public interest. hey could well be added to critically needed
title: SHELTER IN BROOKLYN FOR THE HOMELESS

body: Six years late and nearly four times its original projected cost, Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center opened yesterday as a municipal hospital in northern Brooklyn and admitted its first patients. With a daily Medicaid rate of $557 a day, the huge, ultramodern hospital is $4 a day more expensive than Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in
title: NEW HOSPITAL OPENS DOORS, 6 YEARS LATE

body: She was getting ready for this Saturday's Avon half-marathon in Central Park, doing her customary jogging in McCarren Park in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. She appeared to be catching her breath, looking at the ground, when two elderly men approached. ''You stare at the ground as if you're praying,'' said one. ''I am praying,'' said the
title: SCOUTING; Stopping to Pray

title: CITY VOTE FOR TOP STATE OFFICES BY ASSEMBLY DISTRICTS; DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR GOVERNOR

body: Four persons, including a mother and her two children, were killed in a predawn fire yesterday in their apartment building in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, according to fire officials, who said the blaze was arson. Several hours later, a 25-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested on murder and arson charges in his room at Greenpoint Hospital,
title: 4 RESIDENTS DIE IN BROOKLYN FIRE; SUSPECT ARRESTED

body: Pomander Walk on Manhattan's West Side and the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn won landmark status yesterday from the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission. Pomander Walk is a 61-year-old enclave of neo-Tudor buildings from 94th to 95th Streets between Broadway and West End Avenue. It was designed, the commission said, ''to evoke the atmosphere
title: 2 Sites Are Designated As Landmarks by City

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: A Better Mark for Streets L ast month, 64 percent of New York's 6,000 miles of streets were ''acceptably clean,'' according to Project Scorecard. A year ago August, only 57 percent made the grade. Project Scorecard is the city's way of measuring street litter. Every month 12 trained inspectors from the Mayor's office examine 6,640 blocks and give
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: A 24-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged last night in the death of her 23-month-old daughter, the police said. The woman, identified as Nolin Delgado of 890 Flushing Avenue in the Bushwick section, was arrested and charged with criminally negligent homicide 10 hours after she took her daughter, Rosa, to Greenpoint Hospital with multiple bruises,
title: Mother Held in Child's Death

body: Provisions of the tax bill approved by Congress this week will make it possible to begin renovations by January on 4,200 dilapidated apartments in New York City, officials of the state and city said yesterday. The bill will also enable low- and moderate-income people to buy lower-priced cooperative apartments more easily. However, the officials
title: CITY'S HOUSING TO BENEFIT FROM NEW U.S. TAX BILL

body: The arrest of a Brooklyn surgeon on charges of conspiring to hire a gunman to kill his wife was the culmination of a weeklong investigation by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office that began with a tip from the New York State Health Department, a spokesman for the District Attorney's office said yesterday. The lead was forwarded to District
title: TIP FROM HEALTH DEPT. SAID TO HAVE LED TO SURGEON'S ARREST

body: A 52-year-old surgeon from Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with seeking to hire a ''contract killer'' to murder his estranged wife, a pathologist who lives upstate, authorities said. The surgeon was identified as Dr. Charles T.B. Moyo, a Canadian citizen who lives at 192 Forbell Street and practices at Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn
title: THE CITY; Surgeon Accused Of Seeking Murder

body: A Postal Lesson In Subtraction I t's not vandalism but economy that is claiming hundreds of mailboxes around town. Brooklyn has lost 386, or 17 percent, since March, leaving it with 1,946. Manhattan has lost 250, nearly 10 percent, since June. Queens and Staten Island, losing more than 2 percent, still have 4,000 and 504 boxes respectively, while
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: N ear the McGuinness Boulevard exit in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, westbound traffic on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway sputtered yesterday, just as traffic planners had expected. They had closed off a large section of the right lane for one of the many jobs in this city that tend to be short on glamour but could be long on consequence. For
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Reflections

body: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that New York City may continue with its plan to replace the 67-year-old Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn with the modern Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center. The decision, issued by Justice William T. Bellard in Brooklyn, modified his injunction of May 21 against the plan developed by the city's Health
title: COURT UPHOLDS CLOSING OF GREENPOINT HOSPITAL

body: Two gunmen held up an armored truck in Brooklyn at about 6:30 P.M. yesterday and escaped with $420,000, the police said. The truck, which belonged to IBI Security of Long Island City, Queens, was taken over while stopped for a light at the intersection of Humboldt Street and McGuiness Boulevard, in the Greenpoint section, according a police
title: THE CITY; Armored Truck Robbed of $420,000

body: The Conservative Party gave Lewis E. Lehrman its nomination for Governor today, insuring that he will be on the November ballot no matter what happens in the Republican primary. An effort to let his Republican rival, Paul J. Curran, compete in a Conservative primary was rejected by party leaders. In a one-day meeting at the Turf Inn in this Albany
title: NEW YORK'S MINOR PARTIES SELECT STATEWIDE CANDIDATES

body: The police said they were searching yesterday for a suspect in several robberies and a homicide who fired two shots at officers trying to capture him in Brooklyn Saturday night. One officer was slightly injured by flying glass from a bullet-pierced patrol car windshield. The suspect, identified by the police as 22-year-old Felix Lagoy, was seen by
title: THE CITY

body: A man suspected of robbery and homicide fired at least two shots at a police car in Brooklyn last night, the police said. An officer inside was cut on the hand by flying glass when a window shattered. The injured officer, Dennis Doyle, of the 90th Precinct, was treated at Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn and released, according to Sgt. Tom Fahey, a
title: A Shot Hits Police Car; Officer Is Hurt by Glass

body: Possible delays in Justice Department approval of New York's new political boundaries could force postponement of the state's primary election, now scheduled for Sept. 14, according to key legislators. The primary will likely be postponed, they say, unless the Government makes a decision by next Thursday, when a Federal court is to hold a hearing
title: LEGISLATORS FEAR DELAY IN NEW YORK STATE PRIMARY

body: Woodhull Hospital, a multimillion-dollar structure that has stood unused in Brooklyn for four years, is to accept its first patients today. Woodhull's family-care center will be the first section of the hospital to go into operation, according to Thomas Ricke, a spokesman for the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. He said the other sections
title: THE CITY; Woodhull Hospital Taking Patients

body: More than 100 new General Motors buses are sitting idle in New York City bus depots because of a dispute between the Transit Authority and General Motors over the operation of the vehicles' rear exit doors. The authority says that it is afraid to use the new buses because of problems that developed with an earlier order of General Motors buses;
title: 100 NEW G.M. BUSES SIT IDLE IN DISPUTE OVER REAR DOORS

body: Ted Weiss does not want to go to Queens. Olga A. Mendez does not want to leave Roosevelt Island. Thomas J. Bartosiewicz says, ''I kind of like Staten Island, but ...'' But Mr. Bartosiewicz would kind of like to continue representing the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn in the State Senate and not have to search for new, farflung constituents, as is
title: REDISTRICTING WORRYING NEW YORK LAWMAKERS

body: ''SNOW Orchid'' may sound like a cryptic title for a play about a warring Italian-American family in Brooklyn, but it proves not nearly cryptic enough. The explanation is announced in Act II, just after the father's prized collection of potted orchids has been thrown into a snow-covered garbage can. ''Orchid plants are tough,'' we're reassured,
title: DRAMA: JOE PINTAURO'S 'SNOE ORCHID'

body: An off-duty state correction officer was shot last night when two men tried to rob him while he was sitting in his car in Brooklyn, the police said. The officer, 44-year-old Alvin Walker, was taken to Greenpoint Hospital after being attacked at about 7 P.M. at the corner of Park and Throop Avenues. He was listed in serious condition.
title: Off-Duty Jail Guard Is Shot

body: The Brooklyn warehouse of Granada TV, a television and video rental company, was robbed of an estimated $50,000 worth of equipment yesterday by four men, one of whom was a former employee, the police said. According to the police account, the warehouse supervisor, who was not identified, reported that one of the robbers was a recently dismissed
title: 4 Rob the Warehouse Of TV Rental Concern

body: A 31-year-old inmate at the Brooklyn House of Detention hanged himself in his cell yesterday morning within hours of a court hearing on robbery and weapons possession charges, the Department of Correction said. Edward Hershey, an assistant commissioner, identified the man as Anthony Stratford of the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. ''He had
title: THE CITY; Inmate Found Hanged in His Cell

body: A suspicious two-alarm blaze destroyed a Hasidic school and synagogue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn early yesterday, a spokesman for the Fire Deparment reported. And last night in the Bronx, two firefighters were injured as a blaze roared through a six-story apartment building in the Bedford Park section, according to the spokesman, John
title: 2 FIREMEN INJURED AND SCHOOL DESTROYED IN SEPARATE BLAZES

body: A gasoline tanker exploded, burst into flames and sank in the East River yesterday morning, killing one crew member and injuring three others, moments after it passed under the Williamsburg Bridge. A huge chunk of steel was flung 135 feet into the air and landed on the subway tracks of the bridge, halting one train and closing the bridge to cars
title: SEAMAN IS KILLED AS TANKER SINKS INTO EAST RIVER

body: The New York City Department of Health released the names of 29 food establishments found to be in violation of the city's health codes. Following a final re-inspection, ten establishments were allowed to reopen and ten others were closed for failure to correct their violations. These are the establishments cited: VIOLATIONS New Lin Heong, 69
title: 29 Establishments Fail Health Inspection

body: Next year - as in the old Brooklyn Dodger baseball war cry, ''Wait till next year'' - may be getting closer. The State Legislature has approved $30,000 in a supplemental deficiency budget to make a feasibility study of a domed sports stadium for Brooklyn. It is still only a gleam in sponsors' eyes, but the job has been assigned to the New York

Two women were found dead yesterday in their home at 91 Targee Street in Grymes Hill, S.I., after a fire that broke out shortly after 2 P.M. They were identified as Mary Parnell, 79 years old, and her daughter, Marie, 60. ... Two armed men held up a the Sawa Gift Shop at 745 Manhattan Avenue in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn at about 1 P.M. and
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: From his executive suite in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, Vic Barouh can check the sales reports from his $150 million officeequipment empire, call his factories in Ireland and Puerto Rico, watch his Ko-Rec-Type trucks fill on the loading docks and recall the day he started his business in 1955 with $48,000. What he finds himself thinking
title: AN ANGRY BUSINESSMAN'S WAR ON CRIME

body: A fire attributed to arson killed seven residents of a Brooklyn tenement early yesterday and injured 27 persons, 14 of them firemen. Fire Department officials said that the blaze, at 258 Albany Avenue in the Crown Heights section, had been set and that they had no suspects. Two persons died in a fire in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn shortly
title: 7 KILLED IN BROOKLYN TENEMENT; 2 DIE IN 2D BLAZE

body: International A major policy split on Poland's debts was reported in the Reagan Administration. High Pentagon officials said that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger intended to keep pressing to have Poland declared in default of its debts to the West and to prod Western European nations to halt their natural gas pipeline deal with Moscow. (Page
title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1982

body: More than a third of the 42 hospitals in New York City seeking official designation to receive emergency ambulance patients have failed to meet qualifying standards. As a result, city officials said yesterday that they would modify or waive the standards rather than exclude any hospitals. To do otherwise, the officials said, would severely damage
title: CITY MAY EASE RULES HOSPITALS CAN'T FOLLOW

body: New York City housing officials and a consortium of 13 city banks have established a $6 .5 million rehabilitation loan program to aid housing renov ation in 33 city neighborhoods. The program will combine $1.5 million in Federal funds with $5 million from the banks to provide re habilitation funds to qualified applicants at below-market interest
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; KEY HOUSING PROGRAM REVIVED IN CITY

body: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 45 food establishments that it said were in violation of the Health Code. The department also identified one establishment that had corrected its violations and three that were closed for failing to do so. It listed these establisments: VIOLATIONS China Sui, 15 Ave. B Cafe Espanol,
title: 45 FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITED
